text: University of Birmingham School of Mathematics Vectors, Geometry and Linear Algebra VGLA (Formative) Problem Sheet 3 (Semester 1) This is a formative problem sheet and you do not submit your solutions. Do try the questions though and look at the model solutions when they are released. You will be able to try Questions 1–3 immediately. You will be able to attempt Question 4 after the last lecture in Week 7 (i.e., by the end of 12th November). Remember that you should always carefully write out your solutions giving full explanations (not just stating the answer). Q1. Suppose that a = (2, 1, 0) is a vector. Determine the scalar equation of the plane Π perpendicular to a containing the point P = (1, 1, 1). Q2. The aim of this question is to ﬁnd the parametric form of the equation of the line of intersection of the planes Π1 = {(x, y, z) ∈ R3 : x + 2y + z = 3} and Π2 = {(x, y, z) ∈ R3 : x + y + 2z = 4}. To answer this question, we break the task into several sub-questions. (i) Give a normal vector n1 to the plane Π1 and a normal vector n2 to the plane Π2. (ii) Determine the vector product n1 × n2. (iii) Let L denote the line of intersection of Π1 and Π2. Explain why the vector n1 × n2 is parallel to L. [Hint: to convince yourself this is true, you could draw a picture of two planes intersecting in a line.] (iv) Use this fact to determine the parametric form of the equation of L. Q3. Suppose that z1 = 4 − 4i and z2 = 5 + 2i. (i) Calculate (a) z1z2, (b) z1z−1 2 and (c) z−1 1 + z−1 1 z2 giving your answer in the form a + bi for appropriate real numbers a and b. (ii) Determine the complex number α such that z1α = z2. Q4. Use De Moivre’s theorem to prove that sin 4θ = 4 cos θ sin θ(cos2 θ − sin 2 θ) for all θ ∈ R. 1
